analyzed: atha kho āyasmā vaṅgīsaḥ āyasmantam ānandam gāthāya ajjhabhāsi
translated: Then Ven. Vaṅgīsa addressed Ven. Ānanda in verse:
“I’m burning up with lust & passion.
My mind is burning up.
Please tell me how to cool down,
out of compassion, O Gotama.”
“Your mind is burning up because of a misconception.
Avoid the sign of beauty that’s connected with passion.
Look at fabrications as other,
as stress, not as self.
Cool down the great passion,
so that you don’t burn up again & again.
Develop the mind imbued with the unattractive,
one-pointed, well-concentrated.
Keep mindfulness immersed in the body,
and be full of disenchantment.
Develop the signless,
and abandon the underlying tendency to conceit.
Then, with the penetration of conceit,
you will live in peace.”

Well-Spoken
At Sāvatthī.
There the Blessed One addressed the monks:
“Monks!”
“Venerable sir!” those monks replied.
The Blessed One said:🔽“Monks, a monk should be one who speaks in a way that is well-spoken.

original: “Catūhi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgatā vācā subhāsitā hoti, no dubbhāsitā; anavajjā ca ananuvajjā ca viññūnaṁ.
analyzed: catūhi bhikkhave aṅgehi samannāgatā vācā su bhāsitā hoti no dubbhāsitā anavajjā ca ananuvajjā ca
translated: “When speech is endowed with four factors, it is well-spoken, not badly spoken; it is blameless and beyond reproach for those who are discerning.
With what four?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu subhāsitaṁyeva bhāsati no dubbhāsitaṁ, dhammaṁyeva bhāsati no adhammaṁ, piyaṁyeva bhāsati no appiyaṁ, saccaṁyeva bhāsati no alikaṁ.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu su bhāsitayā iva bhāsati no dubbhāsita dhammayā iva bhāsati no adhamma piyayā iva bhāsati no appiya saccayā iva bhāsati no alika
translated: Here, a bhikkhu speaks only what is well spoken, not what is badly spoken; he speaks only about the Dhamma, not about non-Dhamma; he speaks only what is pleasing, not what is unpleasing; he speaks only the truth, not what is false.

original: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi aṅgehi samannāgatā vācā subhāsitā hoti, no dubbhāsitā, anavajjā ca ananuvajjā ca viññūnan”ti.
analyzed: imehi kho bhikkhave catūhi aṅgehi samannāgatā vācā su bhāsitā hoti no dubbhāsitā anavajjā ca ananuvajjā ca viññūnanti
translated: When speech is endowed with these four factors, it is well-spoken, not badly spoken; it is blameless and beyond reproach for those who are discerning.”
This is what the Blessed One said.

original: Idaṁ vatvāna sugato athāparaṁ etadavoca satthā:

translated: Having said this, the One of Further Teaching, the Teacher, said this:

translated: “The good declare well-spoken speech to be the best,🔽Speaking Dhamma, not non-Dhamma, is the second;

analyzed: piyam bhaṇe na appiyam tam tatiya
translated: Speaking what is pleasing, not what is unpleasing, is the third;

analyzed: saccam bhaṇe nālikam tam catuttham ti
translated: Speaking the truth, not what is false, is the fourth.”
